title: Weird glitch on Firefox 93
content:
Hello people,

I've got a weird glitch on a brand new M1 Macbook with macOS Monterey.

The system is set to use a non-latin right-to-left language, so the entire UI is "mirrored" compared to a left-to-right language UI like English.

This includes the macOS semaphore window controls, located on the top-right corner of the window instead of the usual top-left corner.

Firefox for the most part adapts to the right-to-left UI, except it keeps the semaphore controls on the top-left corner instead of moving them on the top-right corner, and by doing so, it cuts the maximize button (green).

I've tried all the solutions I could think of, including:

  • disable the hardware acceleration
  • start in safe mode
  • disable the webrendering from about:config
  • start with all add-ons turned off from about:profile
  • start with a brand new profile from about:profile

The issue still persists.

Here's a screeenshot for reference, as you can see the semaphore is "flipped" because it follows the system locale (so from left to right you have green-yellow-red instead of the usual red-yellow-green), but Firefox doesn't move it on the right part of the window, it keeps it on the left corner so it cut the maximize button.

The correct behaviour (as any other application does) should be to have the semaphore controls on the top-right corner of the window, not the top-left.

Does anyone know a solution to this problem?

Should I open an issue on Bugzilla too?

Thanks.
creator: Snkk

title: The background color of the tabs
content: Hello. I'm switching to a new computer soon. I installed Firefox there, I made it fit for the most part, but I can't find the background options in the tools. title: Open link behavior in gmail vs other sites
content:
Firefox 78.15.0esr Mac OS 11.6

Strange behavior (imho): in gmail, in an email, if I click on a link, it opens in a new tab behind the current one. In any other website, clicking a link brings it up in the current tab.

In any other website, command-click opens a link in a new tab behind the current. In gmail, in an email, command-click on a link does nothing.

In both gmail and other websites, command-shift-click opens a link in a new tab and makes it the active tab.

I have years of muscle memory of command-click to open links in gmail - that's how every other browser I've used works. Is there a setting to make FF behave consistently, both with how it handles other websites and with how every other browser works?
